links.title: RetroArch
links.description: Frontend for emulators, game engines, and media players—an all-in-one solution for retro gaming.

links.title: DOSBox
links.description: A DOS emulator that lets you run old DOS games and applications flawlessly on modern systems.

links.title: ScummVM
links.description: Engine that allows you to play classic point-and-click adventure games like Monkey Island and Day of the Tentacle.

links.title: Lutris
links.description: Open gaming platform for Linux that helps you install and manage games from all kinds of sources—native, Wine, emulated, and more.

links.title: PICO-8
links.description: Fantasy console for creating, sharing, and playing tiny games—popular in the retro pixel art scene.

links.title: PlayOnLinux
links.description: Graphical frontend for Wine that helps you install and manage Windows games and software on Linux.

tips.title: Use Controllers with RetroArch
tips.content: RetroArch auto-detects many USB controllers and gamepads. Configure them in the input settings for smoother gameplay.

tips.title: Preserve Old Games
tips.content: Dump your old cartridge or CD-based games into ROMs or ISOs using tools like CloneCD or Retrode, and store them with checksums.

tips.title: Try DOSBox-X for Advanced Features
tips.content: DOSBox-X adds extended hardware support, save states, and better compatibility for DOS-based productivity tools.

tips.title: Build a Portable Gaming USB
tips.content: Combine tools like Ventoy and RetroArch with preloaded ROMs and emulators on a bootable USB for plug-and-play retro gaming.

tips.title: Explore Open-Source Remakes
tips.content: Many classic games have open-source remakes like OpenRA (Red Alert), FreeCiv, and OpenTTD. Great for LAN play or modding.

tips.title: Use Lutris for Game Management
tips.content: Lutris can manage and run GOG, Steam, emulators, and Wine games all in one launcher—perfect for organizing your retro setup.
